subject: Re: [junit] How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... Public interfaces. Public factories. Package-private implementations, in the package of the factory. Tests in the same package as the class they test.

Elliotte Harold wrote:
> That's basically correct in general. The problem i=
s that Java doesn't
> have a real distinction between public and published.=
 If it's public,
> then it's published. Given that we're working in Java (e=
specially Java 5
> and earlier; things may get better in Java 6) we have to=
 live with this.
> In another language, it might be different; but in Java =
everything
> that's public is published, whether you want it to be or not.
=

Public interfaces.

Public factories.

Package-private implementations, in=
 the package of the factory.

Tests in the same package as the class they t=
est.

Also, for the purposes of JavaDoc at least, you can exclude particula=
r
packages. Packaging into an API and runtime jars also helps here.

In oth=
er words, there are ways around this limitation, if they are
important enou=
gh for you.
